packages.description: A container orchestration platform for Mesos and DCOS.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Marathon DCOS Service has been successfully installed!

	Documentation: https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon
	Issues: https://github.com/mesosphere/marathon/issues
packages.preInstallNotes: We recommend a minimum of one node with at least 2 CPU shares and 1GB of RAM available for the Marathon DCOS Service.

name.description: The ID of this Marathon service inside DCOS base Marathon.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each Marathon instance.

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to each Marathon instance.

instances.description: Number of Marathon instances to run.

uris.description: List of URIs that will be downloaded and made available in the current working directory of Marathon. For example this can be used to download a Java keystore file for SSL configuration.

heap-min.description: Memory (MB) start size for the JVM heap. This number should be be less or equals than the heap-max.

heap-max.description: Memory (MB) max size for the JVM heap. This number should be less than the memory allocated to the Marathon instance (General rule: 50%).

marathon.description: Marathon command line flags. These are the same flags that are passed through to Marathon when launching manually from the command line. See details here: https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon/docs/command-line-flags.html

access-control-allow-origin.description: The origin(s) to allow in Marathon. Not set by default. Example values are "*", or "http://localhost:8888, http://domain.com"

artifact-store.description: URL to the artifact store. Supported store types hdfs, file. Example: hdfs://localhost:54310/path/to/store, file:///var/log/store

checkpoint.description: Enabled: (Default) Enable checkpointing of tasks. Requires checkpointing enabled on slaves. Allows tasks to continue running during mesos-slave restarts and upgrades Disabled: Disable checkpointing of tasks.

decline-offer-duration.description: (Default: 120 seconds) The duration (milliseconds) for which to decline offers by default

default-accepted-resource-roles.description: Default for the defaultAcceptedResourceRoles attribute of all app definitions as a comma-separated list of strings. This defaults to all roles for which this Marathon instance is configured to receive offers.

default-network-name.description: Network name, injected into applications' ipAddress{} specs that do not define their own networkName.

disable-http.description: Disable listening for HTTP requests completely. HTTPS is unaffected.

enable-features.description: A comma-separated list of features. Available features are: secrets - Enable support for secrets in Marathon (experimental), external_volumes - Enable external volumes support in Marathon, vips - Enable networking VIPs UI, gpu_resources - Enable support for GPU in Marathon (experimental), task_killing - Enable the optional TASK_KILLING state, available in Mesos 0.28 and later

env-vars-prefix.description: Prefix to use for environment variables injected automatically into all started tasks.

event-stream-max-outstanding-messages.description: The event stream buffers events, that are not already consumed by clients. This number defines the number of events that get buffered on the server side, before messages are dropped.

event-subscriber.description: The event subscription module to use. E.g. http_callback.

executor.description: Executor to use when none is specified. If not defined the Mesos command executor is used by default.

failover-timeout.description: (Default: 1 week) The failover_timeout for mesos in seconds.

framework-name.description: (Default: service.name) Framework name to register with Mesos.

ha.description: Enabled: (Default) Run Marathon in HA mode with leader election. Allows starting an arbitrary number of other Marathons but all need to be started in HA mode. This mode requires a running ZooKeeper Disabled: Run Marathon in single node mode.

hostname.description: The advertised hostname that is used for the communication with the Mesos master. The value is also stored in the persistent store so another standby host can redirect to the elected leader.

http-address.description: The address to listen on for HTTP requests

http-compression.description: Enabled: (Default) Enable http compression. Disabled: Disable http compression.

http-credentials.description: Credentials for accessing the http service. If empty, anyone can access the HTTP endpoint. A username:password pair is expected where the username must not contain ':'. May also be specified with the `MESOSPHERE_HTTP_CREDENTIALS` environment variable.

http-endpoints.description: The URLs of the event endpoints added to the current list of subscribers on startup. You can manage this list during runtime by using the /v2/eventSubscriptions API endpoint.

http-event-callback-slow-consumer-timeou.description: A http event callback consumer is considered slow, if the delivery takes longer than this timeout (ms)

http-max-concurrent-requests.description: The number of concurrent HTTP requests that are allowed before rejecting.

http-port.description: The port to listen on for HTTP requests

http-realm.description: The security realm (aka 'area') associated with the credentials

https-address.description: The address to listen on for HTTPS requests.

https-port.description: The port to listen on for HTTPS requests

launch-token-refresh-interval.description: The interval (ms) in which to refresh the launch tokens to --launch_token_count

leader-proxy-connection-timeout.description: Maximum time, in milliseconds, to wait for connecting to the current Marathon leader from another Marathon instance.

leader-proxy-read-timeout.description: Maximum time, in milliseconds, for reading from the current Marathon leader.

leader-proxy-ssl-ignore-hostname.description: Do not verify that the hostname of the Marathon leader matches the one in the SSL certificate when proxying API requests to the current leader.

local-port-max.description: Max port number to use when assigning globally unique service ports to apps.

local-port-min.description: Min port number to use when assigning globally unique service ports to apps.

logging-level.description: Set logging level to one of: off, error, warn, info, debug, trace, all

marathon-store-timeout.description: (deprecated) Maximum time, in milliseconds, to wait for persistent storage operations to complete. This option is no longer used and will be removed in a later release.

master.description: The URL of the Mesos master

max-apps.description: The maximum number of applications that may be created.

max-tasks-per-offer.description: Maximum tasks per offer. Do not start more than this number of tasks on a single offer.

mesos-authentication.description: Enabled: Will use framework authentication while registering with Mesos with principal and optional secret. Disabled: (Default) will not use framework authentication while registering with Mesos.

mesos-authentication-secret-file.description: Path to a file containing the Mesos Authentication Secret.

mesos-leader-ui-url.description: The host and port (e.g. "http://mesos_host:5050") of the Mesos master.

mesos-role.description: (Default: service.name) Mesos role for this framework. If set, Marathon receives resource offers for the specified role in addition to resources with the role designation '*'.

metrics.description: Enabled: (Default) Expose the execution time of service method calls using code instrumentation via the metrics endpoint (/metrics). This might noticeably degrade performance but can help finding performance problems. Disabled: Disable exposing execution time of service method calls using code instrumentation via the metrics endpoing (/metrics). This does not turn off reporting of other metrics.

min-revive-offers-interval.description: Do not ask for all offers (also already seen ones) more often than this interval (ms).

offer-matching-timeout.description: Offer matching timeout (ms). Stop trying to match additional tasks for this offer after this time.

on-elected-prepare-timeout.description: The timeout for preparing the Marathon instance when elected as leader.

plugin-dir.description: Path to a local directory containing plugin jars.

reconciliation-initial-delay.description: This is the length of time, in milliseconds, before Marathon begins to periodically perform task reconciliation operations

reconciliation-interval.description: This is the length of time, in milliseconds, between task reconciliation operations.

revive-offers-repetitions.description: Repeat every reviveOffer request this many times, delayed by the --min_revive_offers_interval.

save-tasks-to-launch-timeout.description: Timeout (ms) after matching an offer for saving all matched tasks that we are about to launch. When reaching the timeout, only the tasks that we could save within the timeout are also launched. All other task launches are temporarily rejected and retried later.

scale-apps-initial-delay.description: This is the length of time, in milliseconds, before Marathon begins to periodically attempt to scale apps.

scale-apps-interval.description: This is the length of time, in milliseconds, between task scale apps.

sentry-tags.description: Tags to post to sentry with, e.g: tag1:value1,tag2:value2

ssl-keystore-password.description: Password for the keystore supplied with the `ssl_keystore_path` option. Required if `ssl_keystore_path` is supplied. May also be specified with the `MESOSPHERE_KEYSTORE_PASS` environment variable.

ssl-keystore-path.description: Path to the SSL keystore. HTTPS (SSL) will be enabled if this option is supplied. Requires `--ssl_keystore_password`. May also be specified with the `MESOSPHERE_KEYSTORE_PATH` environment variable.

store-cache.description: Enabled: (Default) Enable an in-memory cache for the storage layer. Disabled: Disable the in-memory cache for the storage layer.

task-launch-confirm-timeout.description: Time, in milliseconds, to wait for a task to enter the TASK_STAGING state before killing it.

task-launch-timeout.description: Time, in milliseconds, to wait for a task to enter the TASK_RUNNING state before killing it.

task-lost-expunge-gc.description: This is the length of time in milliseconds, until a lost task is garbage collected and expunged from the task tracker and task repository.

task-lost-expunge-initial-delay.description: This is the length of time, in milliseconds, before Marathon begins to periodically perform task expunge gc operations

task-lost-expunge-interval.description: This is the length of time in milliseconds, for lost task gc operations.

task-reservation-timeout.description: Time, in milliseconds, to wait for a new reservation to be acknowledged via a received offer before deleting it.

tracing.description: Enabled: Enable trace logging of service method calls. Disabled: (Default) Disable trace logging of service method calls.

webui-url.description: The HTTP(S) url of the web ui, defaulting to the advertised hostname.

zk.description: ZooKeeper URL for storing state. Format: zk://host1:port1,host2:port2,.../path

zk-compression.description: Enabled: (Default) Enable compression of zk nodes, if the size of the node is bigger than the configured threshold. Disabled: Disable compression of zk nodes

zk-compression-threshold.description: (Default: 64 KB) Threshold in bytes, when compression is applied to the ZooKeeper node.

zk-max-node-size.description: (Default: 1 MiB) Maximum allowed ZooKeeper node size (in bytes).

zk-max-versions.description: Limit the number of versions, stored for one entity.

zk-session-timeout.description: The timeout for ZooKeeper sessions in milliseconds

zk-timeout.description: The timeout for ZooKeeper in milliseconds.

packages.postUninstallNotes: Mesosphere-LB DCOS Service has been uninstalled and will no longer run.
packages.name: marathon-lb
packages.description: HAProxy configured from marathon state
packages.postInstallNotes:
Mesosphere-LB DCOS Service has been successfully installed!
See https://github.com/mesosphere/marathon-lb for documentation.
packages.preInstallNotes: We recommend a minimum of 0.5 CPUs and 256 MB of RAM available for the Marathon Service.

bind-http-https.description: Reserve ports 80 and 443 for the LB. Use this if you intend to use virtual hosts.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each marathon-lb instance.

haproxy-group.description: HAProxy group parameter. Matches with HAPROXY_GROUP in the app labels.

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to each marathon-lb task.

name.description: Name for this LB instance

role.description: Deploy marathon-lb only on nodes with this role.

ssl-cert.description: TLS Cert and private key for HTTPS.

sysctl-params.default: net.ipv4.tcp_tw_reuse=1 net.ipv4.tcp_fin_timeout=30 net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog=10240 net.ipv4.tcp_max_tw_buckets=400000 net.ipv4.tcp_max_orphans=60000 net.core.somaxconn=10000
sysctl-params.description: sysctl params to set at startup for HAProxy.

template-url.description: URL to tarball containing a directory templates/ to customize haproxy config.

packages.postInstallNotes:
Marathon-lb DCOS Service has been successfully installed!
See https://github.com/mesosphere/marathon-lb for documentation.
packages.preInstallNotes: We recommend a minimum of 0.5 CPUs and 256 MB of RAM available for the Marathon-LB DCOS Service.

auto-assign-service-ports.description: Auto assign service ports for tasks which use IP-per-task. See https://github.com/mesosphere/marathon-lb#mesos-with-ip-per-task-support for details.

bind-http-https.description: Reserve ports 80 and 443 for the LB. Use this if you intend to use virtual hosts.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each marathon-lb instance.

haproxy-group.description: HAProxy group parameter. Matches with HAPROXY_GROUP in the app labels.

haproxy-map.description: Enable HAProxy VHost maps for fast VHost routing.

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to each marathon-lb task.

name.description: Name for this LB instance

role.description: Deploy marathon-lb only on nodes with this role.

ssl-cert.description: TLS Cert and private key for HTTPS.

sysctl-params.default: net.ipv4.tcp_tw_reuse=1 net.ipv4.tcp_fin_timeout=30 net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog=10240 net.ipv4.tcp_max_tw_buckets=400000 net.ipv4.tcp_max_orphans=60000 net.core.somaxconn=10000
sysctl-params.description: sysctl params to set at startup for HAProxy.

template-url.description: URL to tarball containing a directory templates/ to customize haproxy config.

secret_name.description: Name of the Secret Store credentials to use for DC/OS service authentication. This should be left empty unless service authentication is needed.

haproxy-map.description: Enable HAProxy VHost maps for fast VHost routing.

role.description: Deploy marathon-lb only on nodes with this role.

packages.name: marathon-slack
packages.description: Send selected Marathon event types to a Slack WebHook
packages.postInstallNotes: Thanks for installing! Have fun sending your Marathon events to Slack.
packages.preInstallNotes: This will install marathon-slack... Send your Marathon events to Slack!

slack_webhook_url.description: The Slack Webhook URL to send the notifications to.

slack_channel.description: Optional: The Slack channel to send the message to.

event_types.description: Optional: Comma-separated list of event types to notify upon - eg. deployment_info,deployment_success,deployment_failed. See https://github.com/tobilg/marathon-slack#event-types

log_level.description: Optional: The log level for the log file output. Can be either error, debug or info.

cpus.description: CPU (shares) to allocate to the marathon-slack task

instances.description: Number of marathon-slack instances running on DC/OS

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to the marathon-slack task

packages.postUninstallNotes: MariaDB has been uninstalled. Note that any data persisted to a NFS share still exists and will need to be manually removed.
packages.name: mariadb
packages.description: MariaDB is one of the most popular database servers in the world. It’s made by the original developers of MySQL and guaranteed to stay open source. Notable users include Wikipedia, Facebook and Google. MariaDB is developed as open source software and as a relational database it provides an SQL interface for accessing data. The latest versions of MariaDB also include GIS and JSON features.
packages.preInstallNotes:
In order for MariaDB service to start successfully it requires atleast 1 CPU and 1024MB of RAM including ports. WARNING: MariaDB on DCOS is currently in ALPHA. There may be bugs, incomplete
features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

If you didn't provide a value for `host_volume` in the CLI,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

name.description: The name of the MariaDB service instance

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each MariaDB node.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each MariaDB node.

bridge.description: Whether to use bridge networking mode for Docker container. By default, this is false and host mode networking is used.

host_volume.description: The location of a volume on the host to be used for persisting MariaDB data. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/mariadb`). Note that this path must be the same on all DCOS agents.

root_password.description: Specifies the password that will be set for the MariaDB root superuser account, required.

name.description: The name of a database to be created on image startup, optional.

username.description: The username of a user to be created with superuser access to this database only, optional.

password.description: The password for a user to be created with superuser access to this database only., optional.

packages.preInstallNotes: We require a minimum of one node with at least 4 CPUs and 16GB of RAM available for MemSQL.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each MemSQL scheduler instance.

enabled.description: Whether framework authentication should be used

principal.description: The Mesos principal used for authentication.

packages.postUninstallNotes: Service uninstalled. Note that any persisting data still exists and will need to be manually removed.
packages.name: mongodb
packages.description: MongoDB is an open-source, document database designed for ease of development and scaling.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Service installed.

Default credentials: `admin`/`password`.
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

```Advanced Installation options```

storage / *persistence*: create local persistent volumes for internal storage files to survive across restarts or failures.

storage / *host_volume*:  if persistence is not selected, this package can use a local volume in the host for storage, like a local directory or an NFS mount. The parameter *host_volume* controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which MUST be the same on all nodes of the cluster.

NOTE: If you didn't select persistence in the storage section, or provided a valid value for *host_volume* on installation,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

networking / *port*: This DC/OS service can be accessed from any other application through a NAMED VIP in the format *`service_name.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:port`*. Check status of the VIP in the *Network* tab of the DC/OS Dashboard (Enterprise DC/OS only).

networking / *external_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the service from outside of the cluster

networking / *external_access_port*: port to be used in Marathon-LB for accessing the service.

networking / *external_ui_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the status UI web page

name.description: Name of this service instance.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each service instance.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each service instance.

name.description: The name of a database to be created on startup.

username.description: The username of a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

password.description: The password for a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

status_ui_auth.description: Enable authentication to the status web UI

enable.description: Enable or disable persistent storage.

volume_size.description: If a new volume is to be created, this controls its size in MBs.

host_volume.description: If using non-persistent volumes (local volumes), this sets the location of a volume on the host to be used for the service. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/service_name`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents. NOTE: if you don't change the default /tmp value, YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

enable.description: Enable or disable using a specific storage engine.

storage_engine.description: Specific storage engine to be used.

port.description: Port number to be used for database clear communication internally to the cluster.

host_mode.description: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

external_access.description:
Enable access to the service from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

external_ui_access.description:
Enable access to the web status UI page from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access to the web status UI through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_ui_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

virtual_host.description: For external access, Virtual Host URL to be used in the external load balancer.

Service installed.

Default credentials: `admin`/`password`.
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

```Advanced Installation options```

storage / *persistence*: create local persistent volumes for internal storage files to survive across restarts or failures.

storage / persistence / *external*: create external persistent volumes. This allows to use an external storage system such as Amazon EBS, OpenStack Cinder, EMC Isilon, EMC ScaleIO, EMC XtremIO, EMC VMAX and Google Compute Engine persistent storage. *NOTE*: To use external volumes with DC/OS, you MUST enable them during CLI or Advanced installation.

storage / *host_volume*:  if persistence is not selected, this package can use a local volume in the host for storage, like a local directory or an NFS mount. The parameter *host_volume* controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which MUST be the same on all nodes of the cluster.

NOTE: If you didn't select persistence in the storage section, or provided a valid value for *host_volume* on installation,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

networking / *port*: This DC/OS service can be accessed from any other application through a NAMED VIP in the format *`service_name.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:port`*. Check status of the VIP in the *Network* tab of the DC/OS Dashboard (Enterprise DC/OS only).

networking / *external_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the service from outside of the cluster

networking / *external_access_port*: port to be used in Marathon-LB for accessing the service.

networking / *external_ui_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the status UI web page

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each service instance.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each service instance.

name.description: The name of a database to be created on startup.

username.description: The username of a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

password.description: The password for a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

status_ui_auth.description: Enable authentication to the status web UI

host_volume.description: If using non-persistent volumes (local volumes), this sets the location of a volume on the host to be used for the service. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/service_name`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents. NOTE: if you don't change the default /tmp value, YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

enable.description: Enable or disable persistent storage.

volume_size.description: If a new volume is to be created, this controls its size in MBs.

enable.description: Enable or disable external persistent storage. The `persistence` option must also be selected. Please note that for these to work, your DC/OS cluster MUST have been installed with the right options in `config.yaml`. Also, please note this requires a working  configuration file for the driver (e.g. `rexray.yaml`).

volume_name.description: Name that your volume driver uses to look up your external volume. When your task is staged on an agent, the volume driver queries the storage service for a volume with this name. If one does not exist, it is created implicitly. Otherwise, the existing volume is reused.

provider.description: Provider of the external persistent volume. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

driver.description: Volume driver to use for storage. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

enable.description: Enable or disable using a specific storage engine.

storage_engine.description: Specific storage engine to be used.

port.description: Port number to be used for database clear communication internally to the cluster.

host_mode.description: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

external_access.description:
Enable access to the service from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

external_ui_access.description:
Enable access to the web status UI page from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access to the web status UI through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_ui_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

virtual_host.description: For external access, Virtual Host URL to be used in the external load balancer.

packages.name: mongodb-admin
packages.description: A Web user interface to administer MongoDB databases built using Express.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Service installed.

To avoid issues with the web interface it is strongly recommended to access this service through the endpoint created in Marathon-LB.

Default login: `admin`/`password`.

Default DC/OS MongoDB connection string (copy-paste into *add connection* box): `mongodb://mongodb.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:27017`

Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents.

packages.name: mr-redis
packages.description: Redis is the fastest in-memory KV-Cache and Datatstructure store
packages.postInstallNotes: Once the cluster initializes download cli from https://github.com/mesos/mr-redis/releases/download/v0.01-alpha/mrr and follow the instructions in github.com/mesos/mr-redis README on how to initialize the cli, you could also use the REST api's directly to create redis instances
packages.preInstallNotes:
In order for redis framework to start successfully it requires atleast 1 CPU and 128MB of RAM including ports.
Note that the service is alpha and there may be bugs, including possible data loss, incomplete features, incorrect documentation or other discrepancies.

framework-name.description: The framework name to register with Mesos.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to the redis framework.

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to the redis framework.

cluster-size.description: Number of the redis scheduler we should have running by mesos.

master.description: The URL of the Mesos master. The format is a comma-delimited list of hosts like zk://host1:port,host2:port/mesos. If using ZooKeeper, pay particular attention to the leading zk:// and trailing /mesos! If not using ZooKeeper, standard host:port patterns, like localhost:5050 or 10.0.0.5:5050,10.0.0.6:5050, are also acceptable.

packages.description: MySQL is the world's most popular open source database. With its proven performance, reliability and ease-of-use, MySQL has become the leading database choice for web-based applications, covering the entire range from personal projects and websites, via e-commerce and information services, all the way to high profile web properties including Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Yahoo! and many more.
packages.postInstallNotes:
MySQL has been installed.
 Default Login `admin`
Default password: `password`
packages.preInstallNotes:
In order for MySQL service to start successfully it requires atleast 0.3 CPU and 512MB of RAM. WARNING: MySQL on DCOS is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete
features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

If you didn't provide a value for `host_volume` in the CLI,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.
This package can create local persistent volumes for the database files to survive across restarts or failures. The parameter `host_volume` controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which can be an NFS-mounted share. This path defaults to /tmp, so if you didn't provide a value for `host_volume` when installing the package,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

This DC/OS MySQL package creates a named Virtual IP for other services in the cluster to access the service in the format `mysql.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:3306` (where `mysql` would be the package instance name used for installation).
If the `external_access` installation option is selected, it also creates an entry in the External Load Balancer for accessing the service from outside of the cluster on port `13306` by default.

 You can administer this service easily installing the DC/OS `mysql-admin` package.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each MySQL node.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each MySQL node.

password.description: The password for a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

root_password.description: Specifies the password that will be set for the MySQL root superuser account.

host_volume.description: The location of a volume on the host to be used for persisting MySQL data. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/mysql`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents.

enable.description: Enable or disable persistent storage.

volume_size.description: If a new volume is to be created, this controls its size in MBs. Defaults to 64MBs

port.description: Port number to be used for clear communication internally to the cluster. Currently unused and fixed to be 3306.

external_access.description:
Enable access from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB. Defaults to FALSE.

external_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

packages.name: mysql
packages.description: MySQL is the world's most popular open source database. With its proven performance, reliability and ease-of-use, MySQL has become the leading database choice for web-based applications, covering the entire range from personal projects and websites, via e-commerce and information services, all the way to high profile web properties including Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Yahoo! and many more.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Service installed.

Default login: `admin`/`password`.
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

```Advanced Installation options notes```

storage / *persistence*: create local persistent volumes for internal storage files to survive across restarts or failures.

storage / persistence / *external*: create external persistent volumes. This allows to use an external storage system such as Amazon EBS, OpenStack Cinder, EMC Isilon, EMC ScaleIO, EMC XtremIO, EMC VMAX and Google Compute Engine persistent storage. *NOTE*: To use external volumes with DC/OS, you MUST enable them during CLI or Advanced installation.

storage / *host_volume*:  if persistence is not selected, this package can use a local volume in the host for storage, like a local directory or an NFS mount. The parameter *host_volume* controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which MUST be the same on all nodes of the cluster.

NOTE: If you didn't select persistence in the storage section, or provided a valid value for *host_volume* on installation,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

networking / *port*: This DC/OS service can be accessed from any other application through a NAMED VIP in the format *`service_name.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:port`*. Check status of the VIP in the *Network* tab of the DC/OS Dashboard (Enterprise DC/OS only).

networking / *external_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the service from outside of the cluster

networking / *external_access_port*: port to be used in Marathon-LB for accessing the service.

name.description: Name of this service instance

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each service instance.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each service instance.

name.description: The name of a database to be created on startup.

username.description: The username of a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

password.description: The password for a user to be created with superuser access to this database only.

root_password.description: Specifies the password that will be set for the MySQL root superuser account.

host_volume.description: If using non-persistent volumes (local volumes), this sets the location of a volume on the host to be used for the service. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/service_name`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents. NOTE: if you don't change the default /tmp value, YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

enable.description: Enable or disable persistent storage.

volume_size.description: If a new volume is to be created, this controls its size in MBs.

enable.description: Enable or disable external persistent storage. The `persistence` option must also be selected. Please note that for these to work, your DC/OS cluster MUST have been installed with the right options in `config.yaml`. Also, please note this requires a working  configuration file for the driver (e.g. `rexray.yaml`).

volume_name.description: Name that your volume driver uses to look up your external volume. When your task is staged on an agent, the volume driver queries the storage service for a volume with this name. If one does not exist, it is created implicitly. Otherwise, the existing volume is reused.

provider.description: Provider of the external persistent volume. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

driver.description: Volume driver to use for storage. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

port.description: Port number to be used for clear communication internally to the cluster. Currently unused and fixed to be 3306.

host_mode.description: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

external_access.description:
Enable access from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

packages.postUninstallNotes: MySQL Admin has been uninstalled.
packages.name: mysql-admin
packages.description:
phpMyAdmin is a free software tool written in PHP, intended to handle the administration of MySQL over the Web. phpMyAdmin supports a wide range of operations on MySQL and MariaDB.

This DC/OS package is ready to be used alongside the DC/OS `mysql` package. Other MySQL servers may work, but haven't been tested.
packages.postInstallNotes:
MySQL Admin has been installed.

You can now access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/mysql-admin` or at `http://your_public_node_ip:13306` if you selected `external_access` on installation.

DC/OS MySQL default Login: `admin`
Default password: `password`
packages.preInstallNotes:
MySQL Admin requires at least 0.2 CPU and 256MB of RAM.

WARNING: MySQL Admin on DCOS is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

This package will automatically connect to an existing DC/OS `mysql` package through an automated Virtual IP.

This package is accessible through the DC/OS `Services` tab. If the `external_access`is enabled on installation, it will also create an entry in the DC/OS external load balancer for accessing the UI from outside the cluster, by default in port `13306`. Access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/mysql-admin` or at `http://your_public_node_ip:13306` if `external_access` is enabled

name.description: Name of this service instance.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to this mysql-admin instance.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to this mysql-admin instance.

mysql_location.description: The name of the DC/OS MySQL instance to connect to.

mysql_host_port.description: The port where the MySQL instance is listening on. Defaults to 3306

external_access.description:
Enable access from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB. Defaults to false.

external_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

virtual_host.description: For external access, Virtual Host URL to be used in the external load balancer.

packages.name: neo4j
packages.description: Neo4j is an open source Graph Database. It allows you to efficiently manage highly connected data. This DC/OS package is about the Neo4j core cluster servers, core servers' main responsibility is to safeguard data. You can access the cluster via officially supported drivers from most languages. Installation documentation can be found at https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/neo4j

Neo4j has been successfully installed.
Documentation can be found at https://neo4j.com/docs and https://neo4j.com/developer

packages.preInstallNotes: This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies. The default configuration requires at least 3 nodes having 6 CPU, 24GB of memory and 24GB of persistent disk storage in total. Default credentials are neo4j/dcos. Please change them on first use.

packages.postUninstallNotes: Netsil is uninstalled successfully.
packages.name: netsil
packages.description:
Netsil is the monitoring and analytics product for API and microservices-driven applications.

An auto-discovered topology map of your services lets you find and fix failures faster.

Listen to your APIs, see your apps.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Netsil is installing!

In a few moments, go to `https://<dcos_url>/service/netsil` to access Netsil.

Your dcos_url is the URL you initially used to access your DCOS cluster

Also remember to install the `netsil-collectors` package.
packages.preInstallNotes:
We recommend using 4 CPUs and 12 GB of memory for Netsil.

You will also need to install the `netsil-collectors` package, which feeds network and infrastructure data to Netsil for monitoring.

After installation, go to `https://<dcos_url>/service/netsil` to access Netsil.

Your dcos_url is the URL you initially used to access your DCOS cluster.

packages.name: netsil
packages.description:
Netsil is the observability and analytics company for modern cloud applications. Netsil’s Application Operations Center (AOC) helps SREs and DevOps improve the resilience and performance of API and microservices driven production applications.

 At the heart of the AOC is an auto-discovered service topology, which is rendered from live service interaction analysis. It allows practitioners to visualize their service dependencies and operational metrics and work collaboratively across teams. 

 This enables effective application monitoring, capacity planning, incident response, and deploy management.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Netsil is installing!

In a few moments, go to `https://<dcos_url>/service/netsil` to access Netsil.

Your dcos_url is the URL you initially used to access your DCOS cluster

Also remember to install the `netsil-collectors` package.
packages.preInstallNotes:
We recommend using 4 CPUs and 12 GB of memory for Netsil.

You will also need to install the `netsil-collectors` package, which feeds network and infrastructure data to Netsil for monitoring.

After installation, go to `https://<dcos_url>/service/netsil` to access Netsil.

Your dcos_url is the URL you initially used to access your DCOS cluster.

packages.name: nexus
packages.description: Nexus is a software repository manager. It supports Bower, Docker, Maven 2, npm, NuGet, PyPI, and Raw site repositories. Installation documentation can be found at https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/nexus
packages.postInstallNotes: Nexus has been installed. Documentation can be found at http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/
packages.preInstallNotes: This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies. Having Marathon-lb installed and setting a virtual host in the config is required for being able to access Nexus. If you're using a host volume, make sure that the folder exists on the host you used for host pinning, and that you did a 'chown -R 200:200' on the folder. Default credentials are admin/admin123. Please change them after the first login.

name.description: The name of this DC/OS service.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to Nexus.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to Nexus.

role.description: Deploy Nexus only on nodes with this role. Resources that are assigned to the * role are considered unreserved

local-volumes.description: Local volumes configuration (only used if external persistent volumes are disabled). Local volumes are created on the machine with the hostname specified and Marathon will attempt to re-launch the task on the same machine. Note that if the machine is lost, your data may also be lost.

host-volume.description: The location of a volume on the host to be used for persisting Nexus configuration and data (via Docker volumes).

pinned-hostname.description: An optional DC/OS agent hostname to run this Nexus instance on (e.g. 10.0.0.1). If this is not specified then the task may relaunch on another node than the one it originally ran on.

external-volumes.description: External persistent volumes configuration. External persistent volumes are a DC/OS feature that allow your data to be migrated with your task.

enabled.description: Whether to use DC/OS external volumes to persist Nexus state. By default, this is false.

networking.description: Nexus routing properties for use with Marathon-lb.

virtual-host.description: The virtual host address to configure for integration with Marathon-lb.

OpenLDAP has been installed.i
 Default Login DN: `cn=admin,dc=example,dc=org`
Default password: `admin`
packages.preInstallNotes:
OpenLDAP requires at least 0.3 CPU and 128MB of RAM.

WARNING: OpenLDAP on DCOS is currently in ALPHA. There may be bugs, incomplete
features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

If you didn't provide a value for `host_volume` when installing the package,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

This DC/OS OpenLDAP package creates a named Virtual IP for other services in the cluster to access the service in the format `openldap.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:389` (where `openldap` would be the package name used for installation). It also creates an entry in the External Load Balancer for accessing the service from outside of the cluster on port `10389`.

 You can administer this service easily installing the DC/OS `openldap-admin` package.

packages.postUninstallNotes: Service uninstalled. Note that any persisting data still exists and will need to be manually removed.
packages.name: openldap
packages.description: OpenLDAP Software is an open source implementation of the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Service installed.

Default login: `cn=admin,dc=example,dc=org`/`password`.
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

```Advanced Installation options notes```

storage / *persistence*: create local persistent volumes for internal storage files to survive across restarts or failures.

storage / persistence / *external*: create external persistent volumes. This allows to use an external storage system such as Amazon EBS, OpenStack Cinder, EMC Isilon, EMC ScaleIO, EMC XtremIO, EMC VMAX and Google Compute Engine persistent storage. *NOTE*: To use external volumes with DC/OS, you MUST enable them during CLI or Advanced installation.

storage / *host_volume*:  if persistence is not selected, this package can use a local volume in the host for storage, like a local directory or an NFS mount. The parameter *host_volume* controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which MUST be the same on all nodes of the cluster.

NOTE: If you didn't select persistence in the storage section, or provided a valid value for *host_volume* on installation,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

networking / *port*: This DC/OS service can be accessed from any other application through a NAMED VIP in the format *`service_name.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:port`*. Check status of the VIP in the *Network* tab of the DC/OS Dashboard (Enterprise DC/OS only).

networking / *host_mode: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host **THIS IS CURRENTLY NOT THE CASE IN A DEFAULT DC/OS INSTALLATION, SO ADDITIONAL CONFIGURATION IS REQUIRED TO MAKE THAT PORT AVAILABLE IN AGENT NODES**. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

networking / *external_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the service from outside of the cluster

networking / *external_access_port*: port to be used in Marathon-LB for accessing the service.
networking / *external_ui_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the status UI web page

name.description: Name of this service instance.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each service instance.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each service instance.

config_password.description: Allows password protected access to the dn=config branch. This helps to reconfigure the server without interruption.

additional_schemas.description: Loads additional schemas provided in the slapd package.

additional_modules.description: Comma-separated list of modules to load.

force_reconfigure.description: Reconfigure the service after the image has been initialized.

host_volume.description: If using non-persistent volumes (local volumes), this sets the location of a volume on the host to be used for the service. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/service_name`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents. NOTE: if you don't change the default /tmp value, YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

enable.description: Enable or disable data persistence.

ldap_volume_size.description: Size in MBs of the volume to be created for the LDAP database

slapd_volume_size.description: Size in MBs of the volume to be created for internal storage of the SLAPD daemon.

enable.description: Enable or disable external persistent storage. The `persistence` option must also be selected. Please note that for these to work, your DC/OS cluster MUST have been installed with the right options in `config.yaml`. Also, please note this requires a working  configuration file for the driver (e.g. `rexray.yaml`).

volume_name.description: Name that your volume driver uses to look up your external volume. When your task is staged on an agent, the volume driver queries the storage service for a volume with this name. If one does not exist, it is created implicitly. Otherwise, the existing volume is reused.

provider.description: Provider of the external persistent volume. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

driver.description: Volume driver to use for storage. The default value should be correct for most use cases.

port.description: Port number to be used for clear communication internally to the cluster.

host_mode.description: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host **THIS IS CURRENTLY NOT THE CASE IN A DEFAULT DC/OS INSTALLATION**. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

external_access.description:
Enable access from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB.

external_access_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

packages.name: openldap-admin
packages.description:
phpLDAPadmin is a web-based LDAP client. It provides easy, anywhere-accessible, multi-language administration for your LDAP server.

This DC/OS package is ready to be used alongside the DC/OS `openldap` package. Other LDAP servers may work, but haven't been tested.
packages.postInstallNotes:
OpenLDAP Admin has been installed.

You can now access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/openldapadmin` or at `http://your_public_node_ip:11389`

DC/OS openldap default Login DN: `cn=admin,dc=example,dc=org`
Default password: `admin`
packages.preInstallNotes:
Open LDAP Admin requires at least 0.1 CPU and 128MB of RAM.

WARNING: OpenLDAP Admin on DCOS is currently in ALPHA. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

This package will automatically connecto to an existing DC/OS `openldap` package through an automated Virtual IP.

This package is accessible through the DC/OS `Services` tab. It will also create an entry in the DC/OS external load balancer for accessing the UI in port `11389` from outside the cluster. Access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/openldapadmin` or at `http://your_public_node_ip:11389`.

This package is accessible through the DC/OS `Services` tab. Access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/openldapadmin`, or if `external_access` is selected, also at `http://your_public_node_ip:11389`.

packages.name: postgresql
packages.description: PostgreSQL is an object-relational database management system (ORDBMS) with an emphasis on extensibility and standards-compliance.
packages.postInstallNotes:
PostgreSQL has been installed.
 Default Login `admin`
Default password: `password`
packages.preInstallNotes:
PostgreSQL requires at least 0.3 CPU and 256MB of RAM.

WARNING: PostgreSQL on DCOS is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete
features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

This package can create local persistent volumes for the database files to survive across restarts or failures. The parameter `host_volume` controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which can be an NFS-mounted share. This path defaults to /tmp, so if you didn't provide a value for `host_volume` when installing the package,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

This DC/OS PostgreSQL package creates a named Virtual IP for other services in the cluster to access the service in the format `postgresql.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:5432` (where `postgresql` would be the package name used for installation).
If the `external_access` installation option is selected, it also creates an entry in the External Load Balancer for accessing the service from outside of the cluster on port `15432` by default.

 You can administer this service easily installing the DC/OS `postgresql-admin` package.

name.description: Name of this service instance.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each PostgreSQL node.

mem.description: Memory to allocate to each PostgreSQL node.

user.description: Postgres user.

password.description: Postgres password.

dbname.description: Name for the default database that is created when the image is first started.

initdbargs.description: Arguments to send to postgres initdb. The value is a space separated string of arguments as postgres initdb would expect them.

host_volume.description: The location of a volume on the host to be used for persisting PostgreSQL data. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/postgresql`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DCOS agents.

enable.description: Enable or disable persistent storage.

volume_size.description: If a new volume is to be created, this controls its size in MBs. Defaults to 64MBs

port.description: Port number to be used for clear communication internally to the cluster.

external_access.description:
Enable access from outside the cluster through Marathon-LB.
NOTE: this connection is unencrypted.

enable.description: Enable or disable creating a VIP for external access through a public node running Marathon-LB. Defaults to FALSE.

external_port.description: For external access, port number to be used for clear communication in the external Marathon-LB load balancer

packages.postUninstallNotes: Service uninstalled. Note that any persisting data still exists and will need to be manually removed.
packages.name: postgresql
packages.description: PostgreSQL is an object-relational database management system (ORDBMS) with an emphasis on extensibility and standards-compliance.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Service installed.

Default login: `admin`/`password`.
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

```Advanced Installation options notes```

storage / *persistence*: create local persistent volumes for internal storage files to survive across restarts or failures.

storage / persistence / *external*: create external persistent volumes. This allows to use an external storage system such as Amazon EBS, OpenStack Cinder, EMC Isilon, EMC ScaleIO, EMC XtremIO, EMC VMAX and Google Compute Engine persistent storage. *NOTE*: To use external volumes with DC/OS, you MUST enable them during CLI or Advanced installation.

storage / *host_volume*:  if persistence is not selected, this package can use a local volume in the host for storage, like a local directory or an NFS mount. The parameter *host_volume* controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which MUST be the same on all nodes of the cluster.

NOTE: If you didn't select persistence in the storage section, or provided a valid value for *host_volume* on installation,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

networking / *port*: This DC/OS service can be accessed from any other application through a NAMED VIP in the format *`service_name.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:port`*. Check status of the VIP in the *Network* tab of the DC/OS Dashboard (Enterprise DC/OS only).

networking / *external_access*: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the service from outside of the cluster

networking / *external_access_port*: port to be used in Marathon-LB for accessing the service.

postgresql.description: CPU shares to allocate to each service instance.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each PostgreSQL node.

dbname.description: Name for the default database that is created when the image is first started.

initdbargs.description: Arguments to send to postgres initdb. The value is a space separated string of arguments as postgres initdb would expect them.

host_volume.description: If using non-persistent volumes (local volumes), this sets the location of a volume on the host to be used for the service. The final location will be derived from this value plus the name set in `name` (e.g. `/mnt/host_volume/service_name`). This can be a mounted NFS drive. Note that this path must be the same on all DC/OS agents. NOTE: if you don't change the default /tmp value, YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

pgdata.description: Location of the database files inside the container, under /var/lib/postgresql/.

enable.description: Enable or disable persistent storage.

Also, please note this requires a working  configuration file for the driver (e.g. `rexray.yaml`).

host_mode.description: Enable or disable host networking mode. NOTE: this requires the default port to be available on the target host. This also forces to have a single instance per node.

PhpPgAdmin is a web-based administration tool for PostgreSQL. It is perfect for PostgreSQL DBAs, newbies, and hosting services.

This DC/OS package is ready to be used alongside the DC/OS `postgresql` package. Other PostgreSQL servers may work, but haven't been tested.

PostgreSQL Admin has been installed.

You can now access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/PostgreSQLadmin` or at `http://your_public_node_ip:15433` if you selected `external_access` on installation.

DC/OS PostgreSQL default Login: `admin`
Default password: `password`
packages.preInstallNotes:
PostgreSQL Admin requires at least 0.2 CPU and 256MB of RAM.

WARNING: PostgreSQL Admin on DCOS is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

This package will automatically connect to an existing DC/OS `postgresql` package through an automated Virtual IP.

This package is accessible through the DC/OS `Services` tab. If the `external_access`is enabled on installation, it will also create an entry in the DC/OS external load balancer for accessing the UI from outside the cluster, by default in port `15433`. Access the UI at `http://your_DCOS_URL/services/postgresql-admin` or at `http://your_public_node_ip:15433` if `external_access` is enabled

If not using ZooKeeper, standard host:port patterns, like localhost:5050 or 10.0.0.5:5050,10.0.0.6:5050, are also acceptable.

packages.name: registry
packages.description:
The docker Registry is a stateless, highly scalable server side application that stores and lets you distribute Docker images. This DC/OS package provides a private registry that can be made available to any other component in the system through a virtual IP (default: registry.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:5000).

NOTE: This package requires additional configuration in order to run either in secure or insecure mode. Check the package documentation at https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/registry for details.
packages.postInstallNotes:
Service installed.

NOTE: This package REQUIRES post-install configuration in your cluster in order to work correctly. Please check the package documentation at https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/registry for details.
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

Advanced Installation options notes

registry / http_tls_download_ip: For secure communication, IP address of the host to download the HTTP TLS certificate and key from. This will be used to form the URI location of a valid HTTP TLS certificate and key to be used in the authentication process between the docker registry and the agents running the docker engine.

registry / http_tls_certificate_filename: For secure communication, name of the file holding the HTTP TLS certificate to download from the host with the IP address configured in http_tls_download_ip.

registry / http_tls_key_filename: For secure communication, name of the file holding the HTTP TLS key to download from the host with the IP address configured in http_tls_download_ip.

storage / persistence: create local persistent volumes for internal storage files to survive across restarts or failures.

storage / persistence / *external*: create external persistent volumes. This allows to use an external storage system such as Amazon EBS, OpenStack Cinder, EMC Isilon, EMC ScaleIO, EMC XtremIO, EMC VMAX and Google Compute Engine persistent storage. NOTE: To use external volumes with DC/OS, you MUST enable them during CLI or Advanced installation.

storage / host_volume:  if persistence is not selected, this package can use a local volume in the host for storage, like a local directory or an NFS mount. The parameter host_volume controls the path in the host in which these volumes will be created, which MUST be the same on all nodes of the cluster.

NOTE: If you didn't select persistence in the storage section, or provided a valid value for host_volume on installation,
YOUR DATA WILL NOT BE SAVED IN ANY WAY.

networking / port: This DC/OS service can be accessed from any other application through a NAMED VIP in the format service_name.marathon.l4lb.thisdcos.directory:port. Check status of the VIP in the Network tab of the DC/OS Dashboard (Enterprise DC/OS only).

networking / external_access: create an entry in Marathon-LB for accessing the service from outside of the cluster

networking / external_access_port: port to be used in Marathon-LB for accessing the service.

packages.postUninstallNotes: The Scale Scheduler has been uninstalled and will no longer run. You may need to remove supporting services - scale-logstash, scale-webserver and scale-db.
packages.name: scale
packages.description:
Scale enables on-demand, near real-time, automated processing of large datasets (satellite, medical, audio, video, ...) using a dynamic bank of algorithms. Algorithm execution is seamlessly distributed across thousands of CPU cores. Docker provides algorithm containerization. Apache Mesos enables optimum resource utilization.

New User Tutorial: https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/scale
packages.postInstallNotes:
The Scale DCOS Service has been successfully installed!

	New User Tutorial: https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/scale

	Documentation: https://ngageoint.github.io/scale/
	Issues: https://github.com/ngageoint/scale/issues
packages.preInstallNotes:
This DC/OS Service is currently EXPERIMENTAL. There may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation, or other discrepancies.

We recommend a minimum of three nodes with at least 4 CPU and 6GB of RAM available for the Scale services and running Scale jobs.

By default, Elasticsearch package *must* be running within your DCOS cluster. If you wish to use an externally hosted Elasticsearch cluster, specify one or more of the nodes in comma delimited format in the SCALE_ELASTICSEARCH_URLS variable. For quick-start purposes, Scale is bootstrapped with a Postgres database. This should *NEVER* be used for production purposes as it offers no underlying storage persistence. It can be replaced with an externally hosted Postgres by setting DB_HOST and associated settings appropriately.

If you are running DCOS 1.8 Enterprise Edition or higher, you will need to set the DCOS_OAUTH_TOKEN in the DCOS section of the Advanced Settings. This value can be found within the dcos.toml file under in the dcos_acs_token value on a system with an authenticated DCOS CLI.

Tutorial documentation for Scale can be found here: https://github.com/dcos/examples/tree/master/1.8/scale

name.description: Name of this service instance. MUST BE LOWERCASE! Will also be used as a prefix in all supporting services.

virtual-host.description: Virtual Hostname for Marathon-LB webserver exposure outside cluster.

docker-credentials.description: URI to .dockercfg file with Docker credentials for retrieving private images.

logstash-address.description: Address for logstash service. When left empty logstash will deployed into the cluster.

elasticsearch-urls.description: ElasticSearch URL's for Scale. Note: Not needed if you use DCOS ElasticSearch package.

cpu.description: Allocation of CPU resources for Scale web server.

memory.description: Allocation of Memory (MiB) resources for Scale web server.

dcos-user.description: DCOS User for automation of supporting containers. This is only needed if DCOS Enterprise is installed.

dcos-pass.description: DCOS Password for automation of supporting containers. This is only needed if DCOS Enterprise is installed.

dcos-oauth-token.description: DCOS OAuth token for automation of supporting containers. This is only needed if OAuth is enabled.

db-host.description: Hostname to the database server. When left empty a sample database will be deployed. THIS DEFAULT SHOULD NEVER BE USED FOR PRODUCTION!

db-name.description: DB Name. This database must have the postgis extension already installed.

cpu.description: Allocation of CPU resources for Scale web server.

memory.description: Allocation of Memory (MiB) resources for Scale web server.

dcos-user.description: DCOS User for automation of supporting containers. This is only needed if DCOS Enterprise is installed.

dcos-pass.description: DCOS Password for automation of supporting containers. This is only needed if DCOS Enterprise is installed.

dcos-oauth-token.description: DCOS OAuth token for automation of supporting containers. This is only needed if OAuth is enabled.

db-host.description: Hostname to the database server. When left empty a sample database will be deployed. THIS DEFAULT SHOULD NEVER BE USED FOR PRODUCTION!

db-name.description: DB Name. This database must have the postgis extension already installed.

packages.postUninstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DCOS Service has been uninstalled and will no longer run.
Please follow the instructions at https://docs.mesosphere.com/usage/services/spark/#uninstall to clean up any persisted state.
packages.name: spark
packages.description: Spark is a fast and general cluster computing system for Big Data
packages.postInstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DCOS Service has been successfully installed!

	Documentation: https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/running-on-mesos.html
	Issues: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK
packages.preInstallNotes:
Note that the Apache Spark DCOS Service is beta and there may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation or other discrepancies.
We recommend a minimum of two nodes with at least 2 CPU and 2GB of RAM available for the Spark Service and running a Spark job.
Note: The Spark CLI may take up to 5min to download depending on your connection.

master.description: The URL of the Mesos master. The format is a comma-delimited list of hosts like zk://host1:port,host2:port/mesos. If using ZooKeeper, pay particular attention to the leading zk:// and trailing /mesos! If not using ZooKeeper, standard host:port patterns, like localhost:5050 or 10.0.0.5:5050,10.0.0.6:5050, are also acceptable.

framework-name.description: The name of the framework. Until this is configurable, please do not change this from it's default value.

host.description: The host that the Spark cluster dispatcher will register under.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each Marathon instance.

instances.description: Number of Marathon instances to run.

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to each Marathon task.

mesos-user.description: Mesos user to run the executor under

zookeeper.description: URL to the Zookeeper that Spark cluster framework connects to persist state to. (l.e: zk://0.0.0.0:2181)

packages.postUninstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DCOS Service has been uninstalled and will no longer run.
Please follow the instructions at https://docs.mesosphere.com/usage/services/spark/#uninstall to clean up any persisted state.

host.description: The host that the Spark cluster dispatcher will register under.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each Marathon instance.

	Documentation: https://docs.mesosphere.com/usage/managing-services/spark/
	Issues: https://docs.mesosphere.com/support/
packages.preInstallNotes: DCOS Spark requires DCOS >= 1.7.

name.description: The Spark Dispatcher will register with Mesos with this as a framework name.  This service will be available at http://<dcos_url>/service/<name>/

cpus.description: CPU shares

mem.description: Memory (MB)

role.description: The Spark Dispatcher will register with Mesos with this role.

principal.description: The Spark Dispatcher will register with Mesos with this principal.

secret.description: The Spark Dispatcher will register with mesos with this secret.

user.description: Executors will run as this user.

spark-dist-uri.description: Spark distribution URI.  The DCOS Spark CLI will fetch this Spark distribution.  This variable has no effect on the Spark distribution running the dispatcher or the drivers.  The Docker image running this Marathon app contains that distribution.

enabled.description: Set to true to enable the Spark history server.

log-dir.description: Base directory in which Spark events are logged if spark.history-server.enabled is set to true. Users may want to set this to a unified location like an HDFS directory so history files can be read by the history server. Note that this directory must exist prior to installing the Spark package.

cleaner-enabled.description: Specifies whether the History Server should periodically clean up event logs from storage.

cleaner-interval.description: How often the job history cleaner checks for files to delete. Files are only deleted if they are older than spark.history-server.cleaner-maxage.

cleaner-maxage.description: Job history files older than this will be deleted when the history cleaner runs.

krb5conf.description: Base64 encoded krb5.conf file.  Copied to the drivers and executors so that they may access your KDC.

ssl.description: Spark SSL certificates and private key configuration.

enabled.description: Set to true to enable SSL.

keyStoreBase64.description: Base64 encoded blob containing a Java keystore.

trustStoreBase64.description: Base64 encoded blob containing a Java truststore.

keyPassword.description: An optional password for the private key in the keystore.

keyStorePassword.description: An optional password for the keystore (and the key if keyPassword is not given).

trustStorePassword.description: An optional password for the truststore.

enabledAlgorithms.description: A comma-separared list of allowed ciphers.

config-url.description: Base URL that serves HDFS config files (hdfs-site.xml, core-site.xml).  If not set, DCOS Spark will use its default configuration and read from DCOS HDFS.

packages.postUninstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DC/OS Service has been uninstalled and will no longer run.
Please follow the instructions at http://docs.mesosphere.com/services/spark/#uninstall to clean up any persisted state.

spark-dist-uri.description: Spark distribution URI.  The DCOS Spark CLI will fetch this Spark distribution.  This variable has no effect on the Spark distribution running the dispatcher or the drivers.  The Docker image running this Marathon app contains that distribution.

log-level.description: log4j log level for The Spark Dispatcher.  May be set to any valid log4j log level: https://logging.apache.org/log4j/1.2/apidocs/org/apache/log4j/Level.html

enabled.description: Set to true to enable the Spark history server.

log-dir.description: Base directory in which Spark events are logged if spark.history-server.enabled is set to true. Users may want to set this to a unified location like an HDFS directory so history files can be read by the history server. Note that this directory must exist prior to installing the Spark package.

cleaner-enabled.description: Specifies whether the History Server should periodically clean up event logs from storage.

cleaner-interval.description: How often the job history cleaner checks for files to delete. Files are only deleted if they are older than spark.history-server.cleaner-maxage.

cleaner-maxage.description: Job history files older than this will be deleted when the history cleaner runs.

principal.description: Kerberos principal used by the history server.

keytab.description: Base64 encoded keytab for the history server.  This contains secrets.  Ensure you have SSL enabled before transmitting this data.

krb5conf.description: Base64 encoded krb5.conf file.  Copied to the drivers and executors so that they may access your KDC.  Also used by the history server.

ssl.description: Spark SSL certificates and private key configuration.

enabled.description: Set to true to enable SSL.

keyStoreBase64.description: Base64 encoded blob containing a Java keystore.

trustStoreBase64.description: Base64 encoded blob containing a Java truststore.

keyPassword.description: An optional password for the private key in the keystore.

keyStorePassword.description: An optional password for the keystore (and the key if keyPassword is not given).

trustStorePassword.description: An optional password for the truststore.

enabledAlgorithms.description: A comma-separared list of allowed ciphers.

config-url.description: Base URL that serves HDFS config files (hdfs-site.xml, core-site.xml).  If not set, DCOS Spark will use its default configuration and read from DCOS HDFS.

packages.postUninstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DC/OS Service has been uninstalled and will no longer run.
Please follow the instructions at https://docs.mesosphere.com/current/usage/service-guides/spark/uninstall/ to clean up any persisted state.

packages.name: spark
packages.description: Spark is a fast and general cluster computing system for Big Data
packages.postInstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DCOS Service has been successfully installed!

	Documentation: https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/running-on-mesos.html
	Issues: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK
packages.preInstallNotes:
Note that the Apache Spark DCOS Service is beta and there may be bugs, incomplete features, incorrect documentation or other discrepancies.
We recommend a minimum of two nodes with at least 2 CPU and 2GB of RAM available for the Spark Service and running a Spark job.
Note: The Spark CLI may take up to 5min to download depending on your connection.

master.description: The URL of the Mesos master. The format is a comma-delimited list of hosts like zk://host1:port,host2:port/mesos. If using ZooKeeper, pay particular attention to the leading zk:// and trailing /mesos! If not using ZooKeeper, standard host:port patterns, like localhost:5050 or 10.0.0.5:5050,10.0.0.6:5050, are also acceptable.

framework-name.description: The name of the framework. Until this is configurable, please do not change this from it's default value.

host.description: The host that the Spark cluster dispatcher will register under.

cpus.description: CPU shares to allocate to each Marathon instance.

instances.description: Number of Marathon instances to run.

mem.description: Memory (MB) to allocate to each Marathon task.

mesos-user.description: Mesos user to run the executor under

zookeeper.description: URL to the Zookeeper that Spark cluster framework connects to persist state to. (l.e: zk://0.0.0.0:2181)

config-url.description: Base URL that serves HDFS config files (hdfs-site.xml, core-site.xml).  If not set, DCOS Spark will use its default configuration and read from DCOS HDFS.

packages.postUninstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DC/OS Service has been uninstalled and will no longer run.
Please follow the instructions at https://docs.mesosphere.com/current/usage/service-guides/spark/uninstall/ to clean up any persisted state.

packages.postInstallNotes:
The Apache Spark DCOS Service has been successfully installed!
